awd_titl_txt: ABI Innovation: Authors in the driver's seat: fast, consistent, computable phenotype data and ontology production
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern evolutionary research requires organism character data from multiple branches of the Tree of Life, but the majority of such data are in a "legacy" format that computers can not use. Highly trained postdoc scientists are employed to manually convert them. By one estimate, one year's worth of English biomedical journal publications alone would take a full-time postdoc over 30 years to convert. This manual process is fundamentally problematics for three reasons: First, it does not stop the continued publication of character descriptions in the legacy format. Second, it takes time away from highly trained scientists and preventing them from making new and more important discoveries. Third, it does not address the fundamental causes of large differences (~ 40%)  in the data converted by different scientists, resulting in less useful data. This project will investigate a transformative approach that solves the problem at its root, by enabling authors of biodiversity works to directly produce computable data at the time of publication, eliminating the need for subsequent post-publication data conversion. Scientists will be able to direct use the published data in the new format to address grand conservation, environmental, or medical challenges facing humankind today.    

This research has great potential to solve the phenotype data production problem at its root. It recognizes that authors make (implicit) ontological commitments when writing a descriptive work and that they are best qualified to interpret the work. Instead of limiting authors to any "standardized" terminology, authors will be provided with a low-barrier, efficient, open-collaboration platform to describe characters as accurately as they wish using an ontology built collectively with other authors working on similar taxa. This process makes authors more aware of term usage in the community and helps the community (including younger generation of scientists) converge on best practices. The result will be that all character terms included in the descriptive work are documented/defined in the taxon-specific ontology and the descriptions are consequently made semantically clear, and ready for software to harvest computable character data. The software platform to be developed by this project exposes disagreements among authors and usage-based term status in the ontology, and notifies authors of updates and conflicts via a mobile-friendly app. Taking into account user motivation and attribution factors, the project will design, implement, and evaluate the approach from both human social behavior and software usability perspectives, employing recent results from open online collaboration research and cutting-edge usability test techniques (e.g., measuring user stress levels via eye-tracking and pupil dilation). The success of the project is generalizable to other domains and will fundamentally change the way phenotypic characters are documented and used in biological research. The results of the project will be found at http://github.com/orgs/biosemantics/projects.

por.por_cntn:
Huge amount of information about biodiversity has been published and is continueing being published, but information published in journals in PDF format can not be used directly by computers in large scale cross domain research. 

This project aimed to study the feasiblity of creating a noval software platform where biology authors can use to compose their information in a way that both human reader and computer agent can use. In this platform, authors will be encouraged to use established terms to compose the information and help maintain the established terms sets (known as ontologies). 

First, our survey of phenotype data creators and consumers provided strong evidence that researchers and data managers are equally frustrated by data quality in existing PDF-based publications. Ontology-aware phenotype data editors will be embraced by authors of phenotype data.    

Next, through multiple iterations of design, implementation, and evaluation, we have shown that it is feasible to develop ontology-aware authoring platforms for science authors, in particular, biosystematists. Such platforms enable the authors to use and develop ontologies and produce FAIR data at the time of publishing their human-readable publications, without requiring excessively more effort than using Excel spreadsheets. Undergraduate biology students, after using our software prototypes, reported that (a) the software is useful to learn how to document biodiversity characters, (b) their awareness of data quality issues has increased, (c) they agree that the new tool will help produce higher quality data. Experts (i.e. biological systematists), after using the software prototypes, suggested that everyone working with biodiversity characters should have a tool like ours in their toolbox.  

Our results will boost the efforts to develop similar authoring platforms for biology and other domains and eventually make FAIR publications a reality. This will dramatically increase the availability of FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable) data for phenotype and other large scale, cross domain scientific research. 

We involved students, faculty, researchers, and data creators and consumers at large in this study. While deepening the understanding of FAIR data conceputs in some biologists, this project provided research opportunities for a good number of Ph.D., Master's, and undergraduate students. They have gained sufficient exposure to research process to be included as co-authors of our publications. At least three students moved onto their ideal next step in their accademic/career path because of their work in this project.

Modified by: Hong Cui
